questions.title: What is SOLID?
questions.answer:
SOLID Principles: SOLID is an acronym that represents a set of five design principles coined by Robert C. Martin (Uncle Bob). These principles promote modular, maintainable, and extensible code:
Single Responsibility Principle (SRP): A class should have only one reason to change.
Open/Closed Principle (OCP): Software entities should be open for extension but closed for modification.
Liskov Substitution Principle (LSP): Subtypes must be substitutable for their base types.
Interface Segregation Principle (ISP): Clients should not be forced to depend on interfaces they do not use.
Dependency Inversion Principle (DIP): High-level modules should not depend on low-level modules; both should depend on abstractions.

questions.title: Explain DRY.
questions.answer: DRY (Don't Repeat Yourself): This principle emphasizes avoiding code duplication by promoting code reuse. It suggests that functionality or logic should be implemented in a single, reusable place to reduce redundancy, improve maintainability, and make changes easier.

questions.title: Explain KISS.
questions.answer: KISS (Keep It Simple, Stupid): The KISS principle advocates simplicity in design and discourages unnecessary complexity. It suggests that software should be kept as simple as possible, avoiding over-engineering or over-complication, making it easier to understand, maintain, and debug.

questions.title: Explain YANGI.
questions.answer: YAGNI (You Ain't Gonna Need It): YAGNI advises against implementing features or functionality until they are actually needed. It discourages speculative coding and unnecessary future-proofing, focusing on delivering what is required at the present moment and avoiding unnecessary work and complexity.

questions.title: What is the "Law of Big-O Notation," and why is it important in algorithm design?
questions.answer: The Law of Big-O Notation is a way to describe the upper bound of an algorithm's time or space complexity. It helps in analyzing and comparing the efficiency of algorithms. It's crucial in algorithm design because it allows you to make informed decisions about which algorithm to use in a given situation to ensure optimal performance.

questions.title: Explain the Fail-Fast Principle.
questions.answer: Detect and report errors as early as possible in the software development process to minimize the impact and cost of fixing them.

questions.title: Explain TDD.
questions.answer: Write tests before implementing features to ensure correctness and maintainability.

questions.title: What is the "Tell, Don't Ask" principle in object-oriented programming?
questions.answer: "Tell, Don't Ask" advises that instead of asking an object for its state and then making decisions based on that state, you should tell the object what you want it to do and let it make decisions internally. This principle promotes encapsulation and helps to hide implementation details. It leads to more object-oriented and maintainable code.

questions.title: What is "Cohesion" in software design, and why is it important?
questions.answer: Cohesion refers to the degree to which the elements within a module or class are related to each other. High cohesion indicates that elements work closely together to perform a specific task, while low cohesion suggests that elements are less related. High cohesion is essential because it leads to more maintainable and understandable code by grouping related functionality together.

questions.title: Explain composition over inheritance.
questions.answer: Composition over Inheritance: This principle promotes favoring object composition (building complex objects by combining simpler ones) over class inheritance. It helps to achieve flexibility, loose coupling, and easier maintenance by reducing the dependencies introduced through inheritance hierarchies.

questions.title: Explain Separation of Concerns.
questions.answer: Separation of Concerns (SoC): SoC advocates dividing a software system into distinct sections or modules, each addressing a separate concern or responsibility. This principle improves code organization, modularity, and maintainability by ensuring that each module has a clear and single purpose.

questions.title: Explain the concept of "High Cohesion and Low Coupling" in software design.
questions.answer: High Cohesion refers to the idea that the elements within a module or class should be closely related and work together to perform a specific task. Low Coupling, on the other hand, suggests that modules or classes should have minimal interdependence or connections with other modules. Achieving high cohesion and low coupling leads to more maintainable and modular code.

questions.title: What is the "Principle of Least Astonishment" in user interface design?
questions.answer: The "Principle of Least Astonishment" suggests that the behavior of a user interface should match users' expectations. It means that users should not be surprised or confused by how a system or interface works. Following this principle ensures a more intuitive and user-friendly design.

questions.title: What do you understand by the Open-Closed Principle (OCP)?
questions.answer:
The Open-Closed Principle (OCP), part of the SOLID principles in object-oriented design, states that software entities (classes, modules, functions) should be open for extension but closed for modification. This means you should be able to add new functionality without altering existing code.
Achieving this typically involves using interfaces or abstract classes to allow for behaviors to be extended without changing the existing codebase. The principle aims to enhance maintainability and scalability by reducing the risk of bugs when introducing new features, promoting robust and adaptable code design.

questions.title: What are some common code smells that may indicate violations of software design principles?
questions.answer:
Common code smells include:
Large classes or methods: Violation of SRP.
Long method chains: Violation of SRP and OCP.
Tight coupling: Violation of DIP and low coupling.
Code duplication: Violation of DRY.
Large classes with many dependencies: Violation of DIP.
God classes: Violation of SRP.

questions.title: Explain the Law of Demeter.
questions.answer: Law of Demeter (LoD): The LoD, also known as the principle of least knowledge, suggests that an object should have limited knowledge about other objects and only communicate with its immediate neighbors. This reduces dependencies and promotes loose coupling between components.

questions.title: How can you ensure that a software system maintains adherence to design principles as it evolves over time?
questions.answer:
To ensure adherence to design principles over time, follow these practices:
Conduct regular code reviews.
Refactor code to eliminate code smells.
Use automated testing to catch violations.
Document design decisions and principles.
Promote a culture of clean code and design within the development team.

questions.title: Explain the concept of "Defensive Programming" and its relationship with software design principles.
questions.answer: Defensive Programming is a practice where developers anticipate and prepare for potential errors and exceptions in their code. It aligns with software design principles by promoting reliability and robustness. By validating inputs, handling exceptions gracefully, and documenting assumptions, defensive programming helps ensure that software adheres to principles like reliability, error handling, and fault tolerance.

questions.title: Explain the "Principle of Least Privilege" in software security and design. How does it relate to the principle of encapsulation?
questions.answer: The Principle of Least Privilege suggests that entities (e.g., users, components) should have only the minimum necessary access or permissions to perform their tasks. It relates to encapsulation by enforcing access restrictions and promoting information hiding. In software design, it ensures that classes and modules expose only what is required and restrict access to internal details, enhancing security and maintainability.

questions.title: What is the "Principle of Idempotence" in software design? How does it contribute to robust and reliable systems?
questions.answer: The Principle of Idempotence states that an operation or function can be applied multiple times without changing the result beyond the initial application. It contributes to robust and reliable systems by ensuring that repeated actions have predictable outcomes. In distributed systems, idempotence helps handle network failures and retries without unintended side effects.

questions.title: Explain Dependency Injection.
questions.answer:
Dependency injection (DI) is a software design principle that involves providing a component or class with its required dependencies from the outside, rather than creating or managing them internally. This external provision of dependencies can occur through constructor injection, setter methods, or method parameters.
DI promotes loose coupling, enhances testability by enabling the use of mock objects for testing, and improves flexibility in software design by allowing components to be easily replaced or reconfigured with different implementations of their dependencies.
